events.title: Roswell Incident
events.summary: Alleged crash of an unidentified flying object in Roswell, New Mexico. Debris was recovered by rancher W.W. 'Mac' Brazel and subsequently by the US Army Air Forces. The official explanation evolved from 'flying disc' to 'weather balloon'.

key_figures.name: Jesse Marcel
key_figures.notes: Intelligence officer who first investigated the debris.

key_figures.name: W.W. Brazel
key_figures.notes: Rancher who discovered the debris field.

controversies: Initial reports of a 'flying disc' were quickly retracted.
Witness testimonies decades later contradicted the official weather balloon story.

events.title: Project Blue Book
events.summary: The third major systematic study of Unidentified Flying Objects (UFOs) by the United States Air Force. It followed Projects Sign and Grudge. Its stated goals were to determine if UFOs were a threat to national security and to scientifically analyze UFO-related data.

key_figures.name: J. Allen Hynek
key_figures.notes: Chief scientific advisor to the project.

key_figures.name: Edward J. Ruppelt
key_figures.notes: First head of Project Blue Book.

controversies: Accused of being a PR effort to debunk sightings rather than a serious scientific study.
The Condon Committee, which led to its termination, was also highly controversial.

connections.notes: Although Roswell predates Blue Book, its files and legacy were a constant backdrop to the project's work.
The Socorro case was one of the most famous 'unidentified' cases in Blue Book's files.

events.title: Socorro Landing
events.summary: Police officer Lonnie Zamora witnessed an egg-shaped craft land. He saw two small beings in white overalls beside the craft before it took off with a loud roar and a blue flame. Physical trace evidence was left behind.

key_figures.name: Lonnie Zamora
key_figures.notes: The sole primary witness to the event.

key_figures.name: J. Allen Hynek
key_figures.notes: Investigated for Project Blue Book and considered it a key unexplained case.

controversies: Despite physical evidence and a credible witness, no definitive explanation was found.
Some skeptical theories proposed it was a prank or a misidentification of an experimental craft.
